div.p: >> Joyce Farrell: Hi.
This is Joyce Farrell.
Let's modularize a program.

Suppose you've created
a simple program
that produces a customer bill.

The program starts, and
you make declarations

to hold a customer name
and a customer balance due.

You then input data for
the customer, the name,

and the balance due, then you
output some company information.

You output your company's
name, its street address,

and its city, state,
and zip code.

Then you output the customer
information, the customer name,

and the customer balance,
and you stop the program.

Suppose you want
to create a module

that contains the three
company-related items printing
the name, the street address,

and the city, state,
and zip code.

You could remove those three
statements from the main program

and place them into
their own module.

To place the steps in their
own module, you'd add a header.

In this case, we're going to
call it displayAddressInfo.

By convention, a module header
ends with a set of parentheses.

At the end of the module,
you add a return statement.

That's the point at which
the logic is going to return

from the module and go
back to the main program.

In the main program, you
add a call to the module.

You call the module
by using its name,

in this case, displayAddressInfo,
and by convention,

a call to a module
appears in a rectangle
with a stripe across the top.

After the call to the module,
you continue with the rest

of the program that
outputs the customer data.

When you run this new
modularized program,

the program starts, you
declare the variables,

you get the customer
information,

and then you call the
displayAddressInfo module.

At that point, the logic
transfers to the module,
and the module executes.

You output your company name,
output its street address,

and output the city,
state, and zip code.

When the module reaches
its return statement,

logic goes back to
the main program right

after where the method
call occurred.

Then you output the customer
information, the name,

customer's balance,
and stop the program,

and you've successfully
modularized the program.
Thanks for watching.
[ Silence ]
